ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: architecture of sacred spaces and how it contributes to the worship and sacrality of the building or space
I learned a great deal about different sacred sites worldwide and how sacrality can be represented throughout different cultures.
I learned how to think about sacred spaces critically, engage in sacred spaces, and identify how sacrality is expressed through architecture or community.
I learned how to think about art cross-culturally and to think of religion through its art forms. Formal analysis, writing about art, thinking critically about museums and more.

I learned a lot about art all over the globe from this course. I also learned the ways people view the sacred, and how it's similar and different across cultures. I also gained some good visual analysis skills and ways of assessing art that I didn't have prior.

i learned so much about art and architecture across the entire globe. we learned about many different cultures and their ties to art, as well as historically how art came into being, thinking critically about whether some art was created out of positive or negative experiences.
I developed the really great skill of visual analysis.

So many. I took this course as a "just for me" course, so I had no prior experience with Art HistoryI just loved the syllabus. I think the largest thing is that HSAR requires your brain to think differently than any other discipline. About a month in, I started thinking about how pieces of art of architectural structures were "in conversation with" their surroundings; another big one that's stuck with me since studying Indigenous and African art is materiality or lack thereof. In terms of knowledge, the course is a survey, so I also just learned a bunch about different cultures and places worldwide.
I learned all about the art and architecture of significant monuments/sites from all around the world.
history of art from ancient times to present. Amazing overview.
An overview on art history from the very beginning with a focus on architecture.
Art analysis.

I'm already an art history major in my senior year so I had encountered much of the skills in a previous classes. But this definitely gave me more practice and reinforced visual analysis especially because it was with different forms of art that I had never encountered.
Learned how to closely analyze art and architecture, taking into account everything from the structure to the way humans engaged with it.

Visual analysis, both of objects and spaces. A broad thematic understanding of how a number of cultures from ancient to modern times honor the dead and make places sacred. The course also gives you an overview of major world religions and their fundamental beliefs, from Hinduism to Christianity.
I learned about various continuities between depictions of the sacred as well as how to examine art critically for its formal elements.
Learnt alot about religious art and architecture
Learned how to critically evaluate art and architecture from various parts of the world
Good general overview of different religions and arts around the world.

I learned to dissect the important aspects of art, and analyze more than just what pieces of art and architecture look like, but rather use how they look to determine the greater meaning of its purpose.
This was the first time I took an art history class, and Im so glad I did! I feel like I am much more capable of visual analysis now that Ive taken it.
This class taught me how to analyze and conceptualize art and sacrality in different cultures. I was able to learn how to verbalize and go about conducting art analysis.
learning the critical history of art, religion, and architecture. I was able to learn the fascinating history of many famous architectures and religions that I wasn't aware of.
visual analysis

This course offered a wide ranging understanding of art and architecture across vast periods of time, distances, and a diversity of cultures and faiths. While learning about the differences and connections of these, and their influences and great importance until present times, this course has transformed my views and greatly broadened my understanding of world art history.
So much. I have SUCH a better understanding of architecture, artistic elements, and spiritual practices of a variety of cultures and time periods.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Prof Jung is amazing and engaging and so thoughtful in her lectures. really wish we got class with her in person

Even though the class was asynchronous, Professor Jung was very good at maintaining my attention and expressing the importance and grandeur of each sacred space or object we looked at. I appreciated the way she connected sacred spaces across the world through different architectural or art elements. She taught me the ways in which humans have deemed things sacred and gave me a newfound appreciation of these spaces.

Overall I thought it was a well designed course and I learned a lot of interesting things. I would've liked one or two more lectures on African art since some of that week was focused on ethical issues (which are important, I just also wanted to look at more of the art). If there was any way to keep people on track with watching lectures that might've been good because sometimes I'd slip behind, but I did appreciate the asynchronous style because it made it very easy to watch things on my schedule. I also appreciated the lower workload especially with this Covid semester.

the accessibility of the recorded lectures was nice but i missed not being able to interact with a professor and ask live questions: there were ways to do this online through the course site, but it just isn't the same. it was good to have the discussion sections to be able to discuss what we were learning. i think we could have spent more time discussing some of the more controversial pieces or places we learned about because it felt like we didn;t always do the issues justice.

A major strength was the use of multiple modes of teaching. The recorded lectures were actually a really great way to get an introduction to the context and history of the region of the art. We were then able to take this knowledge and expand on it in discussion section.

I loved the professor's lectures and I also think the weekly TF sections were amazing in allowing students to practice using their art history brains. However, a major weakness is that the course requires 2 papers, but before the first one, we never even read examples of art history writing in section. I think it's important to incorporate writing as well as oral practice into class because the in-class sessions didn't exactly transfer to the skills we needed for the papers. Another gripe I had was that both our midterm and final exams were scheduled within a week of our midterm and final papers, which feels inappropriate at best. Something else I've grappled with is how Professor Jung handled teaching the Indigenous Americas and African art. Instead of doing two weekly lectures for these topics, she assigned outside media that discussed sometimes sacred art but also just cultural significance of these peoples. In some ways, I appreciate the professor's explicit acknowledgment that she was maybe not the best to teach these topics, but at the same time, I felt the outside media implicitly "othered" these cultures, where it could have been a stronger decision to teach them like the earlier content had been taught. In other words, if the professor's expertise is in Gothic French art/architecture, then that means she should know as much about Greek art as Indigenous art, which means to be consistent these should be taught the same. I guess maybe I'm drawing a false distinction, and the distinction Jung meant to draw was art that has been traditionally taught within HSAR and art that is non-canonical in that sense, and for that reason, she relied on outside media for these sections. I still think, though, that if that was the case, the professor might have just educated herself more Indigenous and African art before teaching usbecause her lectures were typically stronger than the outside media (which tended to be more thematic than concrete) anyways. All this being said, the lessons from the Indigenous and African art topics have made a huge impact on me. One quote from Jung was talking about how history of sacred art relies on materiality in a way that many non-Western cultures do not adhere to. So, I've been thinking a lot about the west as a concept and how we implicitly devalue cultures that aren't as easily intelligible to us and how the decision to relegate these cultures to the mythical past is a construct of colonialism. Clearly, I do not have a decisive take on how these units should be taught but I do think that it should be interrogated why they are taught differently, and if the decision after interrogating is to teach them differently, then the reasoning behind the decision ought to be more explicitly explained by the professor.
The video lectures were amazing!
taught me so much that my mom has been getting me to learn on every family vacation to foreign countries
The professor is very knowledgable and a great presenter.
I loved this course. It was just a little difficult staying engaged with zoom lectures. However, Prof Jung did a great job with adding effects.
I liked everything about it. Wish it could have been in person but oh well. Lectures were engaging, section was interesting. No complaints.

I loved the course overall, but one definite weakness would be the framing and discussion of African art. I dont necessarily think this is inherent to this course, but a widespread issue in many art history departments. I think the notion that there simply arent as many artifacts or materials to study as compared to say Gothic France has truth to it, but I think theres always room to make more of an effort to cover cultures with the same intensity. Maybe including more discussions of sacred space and art in contemporary Africa would help with the geographic imbalance.
The recorded lectures were definitely a good way to get the course content across

Pretty interesting materials but it was hard to know exactly what we were supposed to be taking away. It's really a general overview and moves pretty quickly so if you want to go more in depth it might not be the best class for you. Professor was a good lecturer but uploaded videos that were over the amount of time of our class, which was annoying.
I loved this class. Professor Jung is absolutely incredible. I can't even imagine how awesome it would have been in the YUAG.
I loved this class! It was so interesting and engaging.

The lectures were incredibly engaging and material was organized in a way that allowed for connections to naturally arise throughout units. I cant think of any was the course could improve because it was great!

Strength: awesome TF and professor who is very understanding of the students, very cool lectures (Professor Jung did an amazing job with the edits), receive a lot of critical feedbacks for my writings
Weakness: sometimes the amount of materials feel overwhelming
strengths was the clear organization of the course

Overall, the course only had strengths, especially the extremely high quality of lectures and accompanying materials. My only suggestion would be to also provide still lecture slides to accompany the lecture videos, as that could greatly facilitate referring back to the material. 
Another great strength of the course were the TA discussion sections, which allowed us to apply and discuss the concepts learned in lecture, with enriching exchanges and interactions.
Have more than one lecture each for all African sacred art and all Indigenous art
This course was absolutely amazing. I'm excited to see how the African section grows. Beyond that I enjoyed absolutely every minute.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I really enjoyed the asynchronous format of this class. I was able to watch the classes in my own time and go through previous lectures to refresh knowledge on certain topics. Synchronous sections were very useful in synthesizing information from the recorded lectures and practicing how to talk about art and architecture.

I liked the asynchronous lecture style, it worked well for me. I would've liked if there was a way to be a little more engaged with the course since it was all virtual, but that would've been difficult.
the pre recorded lectures were helpful but i missed the human element of the course. a live office hours on zoom once a week would have been welcome.
The recorded lectures were great!
I really like the combination of recorded lecture and in person section. Jung's lectures were super engaging, and I never felt "behind" because it was easy to catch up or watch at my own leisure.
asynchronous lecture and synchronous section was great
Lectures were pre-recorded, and exams were take home essays. I think things worked very well.
I liked the pre-recorded lectures with a synchronous section. Great combination if you wanted to discuss some things you saw in lecture further with a smaller group of people.
Recorded lectures worked
We had to go to a building for our final project, which was nice, but it might have been better if that was made more optional. Seemed like if we didn't, our grades would have suffered.
I liked the shorter format prerecorded lecture, rather than other classes having one long class that was live. It was much easier to digest in small bites rather than one long lecture.

The lectures and how Prof. Jung made them so engaging and used different media to introduce the material made the class both enjoyable and informative. The structure of the discussion section also allowed for engaged interaction with course material.
The weekly discussion section really helps to review the important themes/lessons and think critically about them. The asynchronous lectures provide more freedom in when to watch the videos.
The documentary-style pre-recorded lecture format was amazing, videos were a joy to watch and I'd have friends come and watch them with me. Best course I've taken during the pandemic.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: yes if prof Jung is teaching

I would 100% recommend this course to another student if they are remotely interested in art history. It is not a particularly difficult course, which allowed me to really engage with the topics at hand.

I would strongly recommend this course to another student, especially for those who've never taken an art history class at Yale. This course does not require background knowledge on the class material and doesn't have an expectation for students to know the concepts/vocabulary associated with art history. I really enjoyed this course.

Yes! I would recommend this course to anyone interested in taking an introductory history of art course. I learned so much about how humans define and deem sacrality, and the course has made me more thoughtful in my every day life.

Absolutely! Please do yourself a favor and take this course. If you're an art history major looking at the intro courses, definitely take this one. If you're not an art history major, I would still say the same thing. This course does an amazing job at looking at art yet making it feel very much introductory. Professor Jung is an AMAZING lecturer and truly engages the students in the different religions and cultures we study every week. She has an amazing level of commitment to the material that shows how interested she is in it--which makes a huge difference. I thoroughly enjoyed looking at different religions through an objective and non-critical lens, and I felt that Professor Jung handled sensitive topics very well. She has the utmost respect for art and religion that comes across as both appropriate and inviting. Christine (along with the rest of the TA team) are all so amazing, attentive, and engaged with the material that it makes the learning fun. It is super easy to sign up for office hours and to receive more feedback/just chit-chat with the teachers in this course. There is truly nothing wrong with this class, and I think it would be even better in person.

I really would. I learned a lot and thought everything was really interesting. It was a very good introduction course and I loved the way we looked all over the world and different cultures. The sacred was also a super interesting lens to view everything from. We looked at so many cool things, and the connections were really interesting.
yes - it's a good overview of what art history is, how to think about art, what language is used to describe art, and all the historical and modern-day issues that are tied to or entwined with art.
Yes! For sure, this is a great introductory course for those who are not art history majors.

I definitely would. I took this course because I wanted to take a course simply for my own enrichment or "for fun." I was also drawn to the asynchronous format as I knew it would be nice to have that extra leeway during the pandemic. I'm not sure if having to attend in-person lectures would change my enjoyment of the course or not. As noted, I learned a lot, whether it be regarding content, how to analyze art, or different ways of considering sacrality. It definitely made me want to take another HSAR course, and specifically, deepen my knowledge of Indigenous and African culture.
Yes!  It was a very fun and interesting into level art history class, that was accessible for a stem major.
Yes
Yes, absolutely.
Yes! Great fifth class!
Great class if you are interested in art history! Very low stress, good introductory course.
Yes, I would recommend this course to another student! It is an amazing introductory HSAR course because of the wide range of material covered.
Yes
Yes! Very interesting class

Yes-- it is a great overview class, you go so many different places to see things that sometimes aren't normally covered in an art history class which I liked. I would never have learned about it otherwise, in such depth.

I absolutely would recommend this course to another student. Professor Jung does an excellent job of breaking down sacred sites and contextualizing them. My TF, Michaela Haffner, was also very accommodating and was a great section leader.
Yes! It was a great introductory course to the significant artistic pieces of the world
Yes i would

Yes, if what they are looking for is a general overview, and not a very specific focus on any topic in art history. Material is interesting and profs are nice. I think this class could also change a lot depending on which TA you get.
Absolutely. One of my favorite classes at yale
Yes! I loved it and found the material fascinating. It is a great introductory course to global art and architecture.
yes! not too much work, but very interesting. great if youve never taken an art history course
Yes! You should definitely take this course. It was my point of sanity this semester and I would recommend to all the happiness found in looking at pretty things.

Yes, I never really thought about architecture and its history in creating a sacred environment. Honestly, some places became part of my bucket list to visit. Although the course doesn't cover all buildings in the world, it introduces students to the basic foundation of all buildings such as churches, temples, etc. Really cool and interesting course to explore the world.
yes, i enjoyed the material a lot. very interesting and clear expectations

Definitely! This course is a wonderful and wide encompassing introduction to the history of art. The global approach and variety encountered within the course make it extremely valuable to expand student's views and understanding of the world of art. It is the type of course that all students should take during their time at Yale.

Absolutely. One of the best courses I've taken at Yale, easily. For upperclassmen looking to get an architecture/art history course under their belt for the bucketlist, this is the one. Amazing lectures, incredible professor, super fun material.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Section
In addition to the recorded lectures, this course met virtually for discussion section once per week.
recorded asynchronous lectures that you can watch at any time & a live section once a week.
Recorded Lecture and live Zoom discussion sections.
There were also live virtual sections.
we also had an live zoom weekly discussion section with a tf in smaller groups of about 8 students.
recorded lectures + weekly virtual synchronous discussion section
Discussion Section
In addition to recorded lectures, we had section with TFs once a week.
Section on Zoom.
Asynchronous lecture. Synchronous weekly section
Recorded lecture and live section!
We also had discussion section as well and a few live zoom sessions.
Sometimes we would have live classes where you could ask anything. But mostly pre-recorded lectures.
Weekly discussion section
There were also live virtual sections with the TF in addition to the lectures.
recorded lecture + section
Recorded lectures then live virtual seminar
We had section.
Recorded lectures with sections over zoom
Section, and some prerecorded modules
Recorded lectures with live virtual sections.
weekly recorded lectures
She also included recorded lectures from other people in the art history field.
recorded lectures and readings
Recorded lecture accompanied by weekly synchronous discussion sections.
Virtual live section
